q: What can I do to reduce excessive or smelly farts?
i: Things you can do to cut down excessive or smelly farts
a: Do eat smaller meals, more often drink or chew food slowly, with your mouth closed exercise regularly to improve how your body digests food drink peppermint tea Don’t do not chew gum, smoke, or suck pen tops or hard sweets (to avoid swallowing air) do not wear loose-fitting dentures do not eat too many foods that are difficult to digest and make you fart do not drink too much beer, wine or fruit juice Food and drinks that can make you fart cabbagebroccolicauliflowerbrussels sproutspulses, like beans or lentilsdried fruit, like raisins or apricotsonionsfood or drinks containing the sweetener sorbitolfizzy drinks and beer

q: Can a pharmacist help with excessive or smelly farts?
a: A pharmacist can help with excessive or smelly farts. They might be able to tell you if you can buy something to help – for example, charcoal tablets or special underwear and pads that absorb smells if you should see a GP. Find a pharmacy.

q: When should I see a GP for excessive or smelly farts?
a: See a GP if farting is affecting your life and self-help and pharmacy treatments have not worked, you have a stomach ache or bloating that will not go away or comes back, you keep getting constipation or diarrhea, you have lost weight without trying, or you've had blood in your poo for 3 weeks.

q: What are the possible causes of excessive or smelly farts?
i: What causes excessive or smelly farts
a: Excessive or smelly farts can be caused when you swallow air or eat foods that are difficult to digest. It can also sometimes be a sign of a health condition. Do not self-diagnose. See a GP if you're worried about your farting. Possible causes of farting include constipation, irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), coeliac disease, lactose intolerance, and certain medications. Do not stop or change your medicine without speaking to a GP first.

q: Is farting normal?
a: Farting is usually nothing to worry about. Everyone farts, some people more than others. What's normal is different for everyone. If you notice a change or it's affecting your life, there are things you can do.

q: What can I do to cut down excessive or smelly farts?
a: To cut down excessive or smelly farts, you can eat smaller meals more often, drink or chew food slowly with your mouth closed, exercise regularly to improve digestion, and drink peppermint tea. Avoid chewing gum, smoking, or sucking on pen tops or hard sweets as they can cause swallowing of air. Also, avoid loose-fitting dentures and foods that are difficult to digest, such as cabbage, broccoli, cauliflower, Brussels sprouts, beans, lentils, dried fruit, onions, foods with sorbitol, fizzy drinks, beer, and fruit juice.

q: What can a pharmacist do to help with excessive or smelly farts?
a: A pharmacist can suggest over-the-counter remedies like charcoal tablets or special underwear and pads that absorb smells. They can also advise if you should see a GP for further evaluation.

q: Does excessive or smelly wind have any side effects?
a: Excessive or smelly wind can be a side effect of certain medications such as non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), laxatives, antifungal medicines, and statins. Do not alter your medication without consulting a GP.

q: What are the symptoms of difficulty in pooping and stomach pain?
a: Difficulty in pooping and stomach pain can be symptoms of constipation, irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), coeliac disease, or lactose intolerance. A GP can diagnose the underlying cause and suggest appropriate treatment.
